data.text: Contents
Introduction
Influenza or ‘flu' is a respiratory illness caused by influenza A or B virus. Symptoms frequently include headache, fever, cough, runny or stuffy nose, sore throat, aching muscles and joints.

Influenza is a highly infectious illness transmitted through the respiratory route by aerosols or contact. Influenza occurs most often in the winter and usually peaks between  December  and  March  in  the  northern  hemisphere  .Illness  resembling influenza may be caused by several different viruses, therefore national surveillance schemes are in place to detect circulation of influenza viruses

The  influenza  virus  is  unstable  and  new  strains  and  variants  are  constantly emerging.  For  this  reason  the  flu  vaccine  is  reformulated  each  year  to  match circulating  strains and a  booster should  be given  each year.  For most people influenza infection is just an unpleasant experience, but for some people it can lead to  a  more  serious  illness.  The  most  common  complications  of  influenza  are pneumonia and exacerbation of chronic cardiopulmonary conditions.
This policy will be reviewed every two years or in response to national guidance
Scope

The purpose of this document is to provide staff with information and guidance in the appropriate care of patients with Influenza A in order to minimise the risk of transmission to other patients, staff and visitors.
Definitions

table_items.text: Very small particles that can remain suspended in the air and travel over long distances

Certain medical and patient care activities that can result in the release of airborne particles (aerosols). AGPs can increase the risk transmission of infections. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation Bronchoscopy tracheal intubation and extubation manual ventilation tracheotomy or tracheostomy procedures (insertion or removal) bronchoscopy dental procedures (using high speed devices, for example ultrasonic scalers/high speed drills non-invasive ventilation (NIV); Bi-level Positive

Airway Pressure Ventilation (BiPAP) and Continuous Positive Airway Pressure Ventilation (CPAP) high flow nasal oxygen (HFNO) high frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV) induction of sputum using nebulised saline respiratory tract suctioning upper ENT airway procedures that involve respiratory suctioning upper gastro-intestinal endoscopy where open suction of the upper respiratory tract occurs high speed cutting in surgery/post-mortem procedures if respiratory tract/paranasal sinuses involved Certain other procedures/equipment may generate an aerosol from material other than the patients secretions, but are not considered to represent a significant infectious risk, these include: administration of pressurised humidified oxygen administration of medication via nebulisation During nebulisation, the aerosol derives from a non-patient sourced, the fluid in the nebuliser chamber and does not carry patient derived viral particles. If a particle in the aerosol coalesces with a contaminated mucous membrane, it will ceases to be airborne and therefore ill not be part of an aerosol.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Site Infection Control Committees
Will endorse the Influenza policy and agree any amendments to the policy as decided following any post outbreak review.
4.1.1 Will receive reports following an Influenza outbreak and agree and monitor any relevant action plans developed.
Chief Executive Officer:

Has  overall  responsibility  for  the  provision  for  IPC  on  behalf  of  the  Board  of Directors. In addition, the Chief Executive has ultimate responsibility for ensuring that effective systems and processes are in place to minimise the risk of infection to patients, staff and visitors.
Director of Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) Responsible for:
Executive authority and responsibility for ensuring the implementation of strategies to prevent avoidable HCAI
Organisation to continuously improve the Trust's performance in relation to HCAI
Oversee local control of infection prevention and control policies and their implementation
Report directly to the Chief Executive and the Trust Board
Have the authority to challenge inappropriate clinical hygiene practice as well as antibiotic prescribing decisions
Appropriate information is available for patients, visitors and the public
Assess the impact of all existing and new policies and plans on infection and make recommendations for change
Be  an  integral  member  of  the  organisation's  clinical  governance  and patient safety teams and structures
Produce an annual report on the state of healthcare associated infection in
the organisation
Director of Operations
Responsible for capacity and operational issues relating to Infection Prevention and Control throughout the Trust.
Matrons
They will ensure, as far as reasonably practicable that:
There are adequate resources available to meet infection prevention and control requirements
Ensuring that audits are completed and, where necessary, the necessary actions are instigated to ensure 100% compliance
Ensuring that all their staff receive appropriate training including ‘fit testing' and have the necessary knowledge to practice safe infection control procedures
Ensuring regular evaluation of the policy and procedures as practised in their area of responsibility.
Ensuring staff are able to attend mandatory hand hygiene training
Ensuring staff compliance with Hand Hygiene
Ensuring sufficient supplies of necessary cleaning / decontamination resources are available
Clinical Directors /General Managers Responsible for:
Clinical Directors /General Managers have responsibility for Infection Prevention and Control standards and performance within their units
Consultant Microbiologist /Virologist  Responsible for:
Providing expert advice in line with Trust infection control needs and national policy to the Infection Prevention & Control Team, Director of Infection Prevention & Control and service users.
Head of Infection Prevention and Control Responsible for:
Providing expert infection control advice and support to the Director of Infection Prevention and Control, the Infection Prevention & Control Teams and other service users
Ensuring that education and training programmes are appropriate to meet national guidelines and the local needs of service users
To co-ordinate the response to the consequences of rising numbers of patients with seasonal flu and to ensure patients with flu are managed safely and effectively.
Infection Prevention and Control Teams (IPCTs)  Responsible for:
Providing expert advice, education and training to service users. Deliver Mandatory Education and Training to service users
Participating in daily surveillance and patient management for actual and potential infection
Clinical Teams
To identify patients who have been in contact with a confirmed case of influenza
To identify those patients who are at high risk and prescribe the appropriate prophylactic treatment.
The Occupational Health Department Responsible for:
Co-ordinating the annual staff vaccination programme
Supporting and advising the Trust on the management of infected staff
Microbiology Laboratory Responsible for:
Ensuring relevant swabs are sent to the reference laboratory for testing
Informing the infection prevention and control team of influenza results
Individual Employees Responsible for:
For ensuring their own practice complies with this policy and for encouraging others to do so
For identifying and escalating if there are issues with availability of PPE
Liaising with the infection prevention and control team to ensure all patient known of suspected influenza patients are cared for in the appropriate environment
Providing visitors with the relevant information and ensure they are instructed in infection prevention and control procedures
Transmission

Influenza is transmitted from person-to-person through close contact. Large droplet, direct  and  indirect  contact  are  the  most  important  routes,  but  fine  droplet transmission may occur, especially during aerosol generating procedures.
Strategies for the prevention and control of influenza in acute care facilities include the following:
Annual  influenza  vaccination  of  all  eligible  patients  and  health  care personnel
Implementation  of  Standard  and  Droplet  Precautions  for  infected individuals
Active surveillance and influenza testing for new cases
Restriction of ill visitors and personnel
Rapid administration of antiviral medications for treatment and prevention during outbreaks
Respiratory Hygiene/ Cough Etiquette
Incubation and communicability
Incubation Period:
6.1.1 The time between exposure to the influenza virus and developing symptoms is usually 2-3 days, but can range from 1-4 days.
Period of Communicability

6.2.1 The  period  of  communicability  is  3-7  days,  or  until  the  patient  is  no  longer symptomatic. Immunocompromised individuals and the seriously ill may remain infectious for a much longer period.

6.2.2 Adults can be infectious from 24 hours before symptoms begin through to about 5 days after illness onset. Children may be infectious for 24 hours prior to the onset of symptoms to around 7 days. Severely immunocompromised people can shed the virus for weeks after the onset of illness.
Risk factors
Some people will be at greater risk of developing complications and becoming more seriously ill, e.g. people with:
Chronic lung disease, including asthma
Chronic heart disease
Chronic Kidney disease
Chronic liver disease
Chronic Neurological disease
Immunosuppression (whether caused by disease or treatment)
Diabetes mellitus
Pregnant women
Young children under 5 years old
People aged 65 years and older
General infection prevention and control measures

If a patient presents at the Emergency Department (ED) they must be triaged immediately. As soon as the potential ‘flu' case is recognised, the patient should be moved into an appropriate cubicle with the curtain closed

Samples (nose and throat swabs) should be taken using viral medium and transported immediately to the laboratory. These samples will be sent to the regional testing centre. Swabs are kept in the Emergency Department and also in the Pathology Department

Patients, as well as staff, and visitors, should be encouraged to minimize potential influenza transmission through good hygienic measures as follows such as cover nose and mouth with disposable single-use tissues when sneezing, coughing, wiping and blowing noses
Dispose of used tissues in the nearest clinical waste bin
Wash hands after coughing, sneezing, using tissues, or contact with respiratory secretions and contaminated objects
Keep hands away from the mucous membranes of the eyes and nose

Certain patients (e.g., the elderly, children) may need assistance with containment of respiratory secretions; those who are immobile will need a receptacle readily at hand for immediate disposal of tissues
There is no need to wait for a flu swab result if the patient is medically fit for discharge

All side rooms in the Trust should be used for patients who require isolating either because they are immunocompromised or because they are infectious. Other patients in side rooms will be moved as and when necessary, IPCT will advise
Guidance for the prophylaxis and treatment of influenza can be found on the antibiotic section of the Trust intranet- or contact the Microbiologist for further advice

Clinician and Health Care Workers (HCW) who suspect an outbreak of infection in their area of clinical responsibility must report the suspected outbreak to the Infection Prevention and Control Nurse (IPCN) and appropriate manager immediately
Prevention of influenza transmission
7.3.1  Early identification and isolation of patients with influenza is important in controlling hospital – based cross-transmission.
Isolation

data.text: All patients with symptomatic influenza must be isolated in a single room
A green Influenza Isolation precaution sign must be displayed on the door of the isolation room
The isolation room door must be kept closed
The Infection Prevention and Control Team will advise patients to be cared for in a cohort ward when the number of symptomatic patients dictate this to be necessary

Medical equipment used in an isolation room or cohorted area must not be shared with any other area or used with another patient until it has been disinfected using Trust approved disinfectant wipe (Clinell Universal wipes)
Portable fans may not be used
The use of portable X-ray machines, ultrasound scanners etc. may be preferable to the patient visiting individual departments
The number of personnel should be limited to those necessary for patient care and support
If patients nursed in a cohort area a green Influenza Isolation precaution sign displayed at the entrance to a cohorted area alerting all to the precautions in place
Stocks of PPE will be available at entrance to a cohort area
Patient masking

7.5.1 Where possible, in common waiting areas or during transport (e.g., from the community to an acute hospital or from one area of the hospital to another), coughing/sneezing patients should wear surgical masks to assist in the containment of respiratory secretions and to reduce environmental contamination.

7.5.2 It is the responsibility of the clinician or nurse looking after the patient to inform the patient of the reason for wearing a mask. Patients must be treated with sensitivity and offered the opportunity to sit in an area with other patients wearing masks or in a single room.
Hand hygiene

7.6.1 Hand hygiene is the single most important practice to reduce the transmission of infectious agents in healthcare settings and is an essential element of Standard Infection Control Principles. During outbreaks of influenza strict adherence to hand hygiene principles must be enforced.

7.6.2 The term “hand hygiene” includes hand washing with soap and water and thorough drying, and the use of alcohol-based products. If hands are visibly soiled or contaminated (for example, contaminated with respiratory secretions), they should be washed with soap and water and dried. When decontaminating hands using an alcohol rub, hands should be free of dirt and organic material. The hand rub solution must come into contact with all surfaces of the hand.

7.6.3 Hands  should  be  decontaminated  before  and  after  all  patient  contact  with  an infected patient or their bed area, and following removal of protective clothing and cleaning of equipment. Following hand washing, hands should be dried thoroughly using paper towels that are then discarded appropriately.
7.6.4 All staff, patients and visitors entering and leaving areas where care is delivered should  perform hand hygiene  with either soap  or  water  followed  by drying, or alcohol hand rub.
Staff vaccination

7.7.1  Vaccination against Seasonal Flu and Influenza A is available to staff through the Occupational Health Department. It is recommended that all workers in contact with patients receive the vaccination.
Personal protective equipment for care of patients with influenza

7.8.1  This is worn to protect staff from contamination with body fluids and respiratory secretions to reduce the risk of transmission between patients and other staff. Care in  the  correct  donning  and  removal  of  PPE  is  essential  to  avoid  inadvertent contamination.
Table 1: Summary of recommend use of personal protective equipment

table_items.text: Entry to isolation room or cohort area
Contact with blood, bodily fluids, invasive devices

data.text: Gloves

7.10.1  Gloves do not routinely need to be worn, unless the healthcare worker is coming into contact with respiratory secretions and blood/body fluids. Gloves are strictly single use and must be changed between patients and disposed of into clinical waste. Hands must be decontaminated after removing gloves.
Aprons

7.11.1  These are a single use items and should be changed between each patient contact. Full gowns are not necessary for routine care, the exception would be if extensive soiling of clothing or during aerosol generating procedures.
Masks
7.12.1 (See appendix 1)

7.12.2 Basic fluid repellent surgical masks should be worn if within 1 metre of a patient with flu like symptoms. They are simply there to provide a physical barrier to minimise contamination of facial mucosa by large droplets and to prevent touching of noses and mouths. The mask should not be moved on or off the mouth and nose until it needs to be changed. One mask can be worn until it becomes moist and then changed.  It  does  not  need  to  be  changed  between  patients  in  a  cohort  area. Handling of the mask should be kept to a minimum.

7.12.3 If influenza patients are cohorted in one area and multiple patients must be visited over a short time or in rapid sequence, it may be practical to wear a single surgical mask upon entry to the area and to keep it on for the duration of the activity or until the surgical mask requires replacement. However, other PPE (e.g. gloves, gown) must be removed between patients and hand hygiene performed. All contaminated PPE must be removed and place in a clinical waste bag prior to leaving a patient care area.
FFP3 respirators
7.13.1 FFP3 respirators should be worn if there is a risk of contamination of the eyes by blood or body fluids and during aerosol-generating procedures.
7.13.2 Examples of aerosol generating procedures include:
Intubation and related procedures e.g. manual ventilation and suctioning
Cardiopulmonary procedures
Nebulizer therapy
Chest physiotherapy
Tracheostomy care
Bronchoscopy

7.13.3 Only essential aerosol generating procedures should be carried out. Wherever possible, aerosol-generating procedures should be performed in well ventilated single rooms with the door shut, with minimal staff present. In addition to FFP3 Respirators, eye protection must be worn to prevent eye contact with infectious material during such procedures:
All staff required to use respirators must be fit tested according to COSHH regulations. Fit testing must be carried out by a competent person who has been trained in Fit testing procedures
Fit checks must be performed every time the respirators are put on.

If breathing becomes difficult, the respirator becomes damaged or distorted or contaminated with body fluids, or if a proper seal cannot be maintained, the wearer should go to a safe area and change the respirator immediately
Masks should be replaced after each use
Masks should be disposed of as clinical waste
Gowns

7.14.1 Gowns are not required for the routine care of patients with influenza. However gowns should be worn if extensive soiling of personal clothing or uniform with respiratory secretions is anticipated, or there is risk of extensive splashing of blood, body fluids, secretions, and excretions onto the skin of the healthcare worker.
7.14.2 Gowns should:
Fully cover the area to be protected
Be worn only once and disposed as clinical waste and hand hygiene performed immediately after removal
Eye protection
7.15.1  Eye protection must be worn if there is a risk of contamination of the eyes by blood or body fluids and during aerosol-generating procedures.
Clinical and non-clinical waste

7.16.1  No special handling procedures beyond those for Standard Infection Control Principles are recommended for clinical and non-clinical waste that may be contaminated with influenza virus. Waste generated within the clinical setting should be managed safely and effectively, with attention paid to disposal of items that have been contaminated with secretions/sputum (e.g., paper tissues) in addition to other routine and domestic waste management. Refer to waste policy. All waste collection bags should be tied and sealed before removal from the patient area. Gloves should be worn when handling ALL waste and hand hygiene performed after removal of gloves.
Linen and laundry
Linen should be categorised as infected- placed in a pink alginate bag and into a white plastic linen bag
Used linen must be handled, transported and processed in a manner that prevents skin and mucous membrane exposures to staff, contamination of their clothing and the environment
Environmental cleaning
All isolation rooms and cohorted areas will be cleaned with a Trust approved choline based solution
As a minimum patient isolation rooms / cohorted areas should be cleaned at least daily. The Infection Prevention and Control Team will advise if the frequency is to be increased
Healthcare Cleaning staff should be allocated to specific areas and must clean non-influenza areas first before moving onto any influenza isolation room / cohort areas
Cleaning staff must be trained in the correct use of protective clothing and precautions to be taken when cleaning cohorted areas

On discharge or transfer out of isolation staff must ensure that all equipment that has been in contact with the patient remains in the room and is cleaned as part of the hydrogen peroxide deep clean decontamination process
Visitors
Visitors should not visit if they themselves are showing signs of a flu-like illness
Children should not visit
The number of visitors should be restricted to essential visitors only
Visitors should avoid being in the room during aerosol generating procedures
Staff
7.20.1  Staff should not come to work if they have flu-like symptoms. Contact their GP for advice.
Critical care

7.21.1  Suspected or known influenza patients should be admitted to a side room. Full personal protection equipment for nursing and medical staff should be available in preparation for safe intubation. Viral swabs should be sent to pathology as soon as possible for prompt diagnosis. Critically ill patients secrete the virus for long periods and cannot be assumed to be negative until they have been weaned off ventilation and extubated. In patients with tracheostomies must be weaned off the ventilator before precautions can be stopped. If a sputum specimen for viral studies is requested the sample must be labelled tracheal aspirate otherwise it will not be processed at Cambridge. All staff are fit tested for non-disposable FFP3 respirator masks which are stored centrally. Staff with predisposing medical conditions or pregnancy are not to have contact with this group of patients.
Care of the deceased
7.22.1  Mortuary staff must be informed that the deceased had a suspected / confirmed influenza infection.
Viewing
7.23.1  Family should be able to view the body if they wish.
Training requirements

All Trust staff must undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control updates and Donning and Doffing updates. The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Site IPCCS, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It  is  the  author's  responsibility  to  inform  the  Director  of  Harm  Free  Care  and Associate Director Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
